question_text: Under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, which of the following entities is primarily responsible for enforcing federal securities laws and regulating securities markets?

answers.text: Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)
Securities Investor Protection Corporation (SIPC)
Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA)
Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (MSRB)

question_text: A trader maintains a delta-neutral options position and observes that the market experiences a significant gap move. Which of the following statements best describes the impact on the trader's position and the implications for using traditional pricing models?

answers.text: The trader with a negative gamma position will experience losses due to the inability to adjust hedges during the gap, while the traditional Black-Scholes model underestimates option values in real markets because it does not account for price gaps
The impact of gaps is minimal on options with low gamma, so traditional models remain accurate and no adjustments are necessary for delta-neutral positions
The trader with a positive gamma position will experience losses during the gap, and the jump-diffusion model is always superior to the Black-Scholes model for all market conditions
Traders should avoid all options near expiration regardless of gamma exposure, as gap risk cannot be effectively managed with any hedging strategy

question_text: A broker-dealer is required to register which of the following individuals as a general securities representative?

answers.text: A compliance officer who reviews trade reports for regulatory violations
A customer service representative who only processes account openings
An investment banker who advises on mergers and acquisitions
An employee who sells securities to customers and provides investment advice

question_text: In the context of executing a 45/50/55 butterfly strategy, why would an experienced financial services professional prefer selling an iron butterfly at a price of 3.70 over buying either a call or put butterfly?

answers.text: Because the iron butterfly provides the most cost-effective entry point for establishing the butterfly strategy while maintaining synthetic equivalence to the other strategies
Because the iron butterfly provides superior tax advantages over direct butterfly purchases
Because the iron butterfly offers higher potential profits compared to the direct butterfly purchases
Because selling the iron butterfly eliminates all transaction costs associated with the strategy

question_text: An investor purchases 100 shares of ABC stock at $50 per share and simultaneously sells a call option on ABC stock with a strike price of $55 and a premium of $2.50. At expiration, the stock price is $57. What is the net profit or loss for the investor?

answers.text: $150 loss
$250 loss
$250 profit
$150 profit

question_text: A broker-dealer is required to make specific disclosures to customers when there is a control relationship between the broker-dealer and an issuer of securities. Which of the following best describes a control relationship that would trigger such a disclosure requirement?

answers.text: When a broker-dealer recommends securities of a company in which it has a significant loan outstanding
When a broker-dealer is registered with the SEC and has more than 500 customers
When a broker-dealer is owned by, is under common ownership with, or owns an entity that issues securities
When a broker-dealer has a written agreement to purchase securities from the issuer at a fixed price

question_text: Under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, which of the following statements best describes the settlement requirements for options transactions and the role of the SEC in overseeing these processes?

answers.text: Only exchange-listed options must comply with T+2 settlement requirements, while over-the-counter options are exempt from SEC oversight of settlement processes
All options settlements are automatically processed by the SEC through its centralized settlement system and require no broker-dealer involvement
Options transactions settle on a futures-type basis with no fixed settlement date, and the SEC has no regulatory authority over option settlement procedures

Options transactions must settle within a specified timeframe, typically T+2, and the SEC has authority to enforce compliance with settlement procedures and regulate the activities of broker-dealers involved in option settlements

question_text: A portfolio manager wants to protect a $100 million portfolio against a decline below $90 million. Instead of purchasing a put option, the manager uses dynamic hedging to replicate the characteristics of a $90 million call option. Which of the following best describes how the manager would implement this strategy?

answers.text: The manager would sell a $90 million call option and buy a $100 million put option to create a covered call position
The manager would purchase index futures contracts to create a synthetic put option with the same payoff as the desired protective put
The manager would continuously adjust the portfolio by buying or selling portions of the underlying securities to maintain a delta-neutral position that replicates the call option's behavior
The manager would establish a fixed ratio of stocks to bonds that matches the expected return of the portfolio

question_text: A customer buys $90,000 worth of stock on margin and meets the initial Regulation T requirement by depositing $45,000. The debit balance is $45,000. What is the maximum market value that the securities can decline to before the account reaches minimum maintenance level?
Under FINRA Rule 4513, how long must a dealer firm retain records of written customer complaints?

answers.text: Six years
Four years
Lifetime
One year

tags: customer complaint procedures and record retention
topic: Customer Complaint Procedures and Record Retention
